column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Ms.
#Text=King: I am particularly honoured today, as\r
#Text=Special Adviser on Gender Issues, to have the\r
#Text=opportunity to speak in this debate, which is so\r
#Text=historic, when for the first time the Council has decided\r
#Text=to devote an entire open discussion to the topic\r
#Text="Women and peace and security".
#Text=It is only fairly recently that the experience of\r
#Text=women and girls in armed conflict has been discussed,\r
#Text=and then discussion has usually concentrated on their\r
#Text=role as victims.
#Text=Today's debate will show that we have\r
#Text=come a long way in a relatively short time.
#Text=Your\r
#Text=country's strong leadership, Mr.
#Text=President, in holding\r
#Text=the landmark May seminar which marked this year's\r
#Text=tenth anniversary of the United Nations Transition\r
#Text=Assistance Group resulted in the historic Windhoek\r
#Text=Declaration and Namibia Plan of Action on\r
#Text="Mainstreaming a Gender Perspective in\r
#Text=Multidimensional Peace Support Operations".
#Text=This\r
#Text=achievement has won universal admiration among all\r
#Text=those fighting for women's right to participate in all\r
#Text=aspects of the peace process.
#Text=It and your distinguished\r
#Text=chairing of the General Assembly's twenty-third\r
#Text=special session, "Women 2000: gender equality,\r
#Text=development and peace for the twenty-first century",\r
#Text=which immediately followed in June, constitute\r
#Text=important steps along the way to considering the\r
#Text=United Nations peace operations from the point of view\r
#Text=of both women and men.
#Text=Other important developments have led to today's\r
#Text=meeting.
#Text=They include the Council's decision to take a\r
#Text=thematic approach to its work; the recognition that the\r
#Text=Council gave - under the chair of Bangladesh - on\r
#Text=International Women's Day, 8 March, to women as\r
#Text=actors in the peace process; the discussion on the\r
#Text=situation of women in Afghanistan, which took place in\r
#Text=April, led by the representative of Canada; and the\r
#Text=Council's resolution 1314 (2000) of 11 August.
#Text=The timeliness of this discussion is also\r
#Text=significant.
#Text=The Secretary-General has just returned\r
#Text=from an area where he undoubtedly had an opportunity\r
#Text=to see at first hand the role women and men should\r
#Text=play in their societies to bring about peace and to\r
#Text=rebuild those societies.
#Text=The discussion also coincides\r
#Text=with the consideration of the Brahimi Panel's report\r
#Text=(8/2000/809) on peace operations and its\r
#Text=implementation.
#Text=There are three broad areas to be considered in\r
#Text=the context of today's discussion: how armed conflict\r
#Text=affects women; how women actually respond to\r
#Text=conflict, the peace process and post-conflict\r
#Text=reconstruction; and how we plan strategically for a\r
#Text=future in which women are equal partners with men in\r
#Text=enhancing our effectiveness in peace operations.
#Text=Today I would like to concentrate on the two\r
#Text=latter points, drawing on my experience as Chief of\r
#Text=Mission in the United Nations Observer Mission in\r
#Text=South Africa (UNOMSA).
#Text=What do women actually do in conflict situations,\r
#Text=and how do they respond?
#Text=The Secretary-General has\r
#Text=repeatedly emphasized the changing nature of war.
#Text=He\r
#Text=has noted that modern warfare is increasingly\r
#Text=conducted within, rather than between, States, and that\r
#Text=the Security Council is now called on to deal with such\r
#Text=conflicts.
#Text=He has stressed that more and more non-State\r
#Text=actors are protagonists in armed conflict; even children\r
#Text=become involved.
#Text=The proliferation of small arms and\r
#Text=the ease with which they can be acquired, clearly\r
#Text=shown in the Department for Disarmament Affairs and\r
#Text=Department of Public Information video documentary\r
#Text="Armed to the Teeth", has also added a new dimension.
#Text=The socio-economic fabric of a country has now\r
#Text=to be the major focus of attention.
#Text=Societal dynamics\r
#Text=thus become a key guide to finding entry points into\r
#Text=resolving disputes.
#Text=Groups within each society, and\r
#Text=especially women's groups, non-governmental,\r
#Text=religious and other groups, have a major role to play.
#Text=Whether these groups were formed before the conflict\r
#Text=or during it is not important.
#Text=What is important is that\r
#Text=they must be part of all stages of the peace\r
#Text=negotiations, in planning for the future, in rebuilding\r
#Text=and in crafting preventive strategies to avoid conflict.
#Text=Often, those of us who have seen the value of\r
#Text=women's participation in peace operations at first hand\r
#Text=are challenged by the sceptics to present empirical\r
#Text=rather than anecdotal findings.
#Text=In this connection, I am\r
#Text=pleased to report on the results of a joint three-year\r
#Text=effort of the Department of Peacekeeping Operations\r
#Text=(DPKO), my office and the Division for the\r
#Text=Advancement of Women of the Department of\r
#Text=Economic and Social Affairs, a study that was\r
#Text=supported by the generous funding of several Member\r
#Text=States.
#Text=This study, "Mainstreaming a Gender\r
#Text=Perspective in Multidimensional Peace Operations" has\r
#Text=just been finalized.
#Text=The study looks at five peace operations, in\r
#Text=Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cambodia, El Salvador,\r
#Text=Namibia and South Africa.
#Text=It answers the sceptics by\r
#Text=giving objective and empirical findings on what\r
#Text=women staff do in missions; whether and how they\r
#Text=influence the outcomes; and how their participating\r
#Text=equally with men can improve the efficiency of United\r
#Text=Nations peacekeeping.
#Text=The Windhoek Declaration and\r
#Text=the Namibia Plan of Action were informed by these\r
#Text=findings.
#Text=Exactly what does this study tell us?
#Text=It shows\r
#Text=unequivocally that when there is a critical mass of\r
#Text=women in a mission - at least 30 per cent - local\r
#Text=women are more easily mobilized to join peace\r
#Text=committees.
#Text=This occurred in South Africa, El Salvador\r
#Text=and Namibia, where women actively promoted voter\r
#Text=education and the rights of individual women to vote.
#Text=In other words, women's participation in United\r
#Text=Nations missions empowers local women and may\r
#Text=inspire them to organize for the achievement of a\r
#Text=democratic society.
#Text=Women's participation has the capacity to expand\r
#Text=the debate a little further so that it may encompass\r
#Text=more diverse subjects, including those that may be\r
#Text=more relevant to women and children.
#Text=Women are\r
#Text=frequently less hierarchical in dealing with local\r
#Text=communities and listen more, thereby having better\r
#Text=insights into the root causes of conflict.
#Text=Local women\r
#Text=are more likely to confide in women peacekeepers on\r
#Text=such matters as rape and other sexual violence.
#Text=The\r
#Text=presence of a critical mass of women appears to foster\r
#Text=confidence and trust among the local population, and\r
#Text=this is critical to successful operations, such as in El\r
#Text=Salvador.
#Text=Women are active negotiators and able to see\r
#Text=more clearly issues that affect women differently than\r
#Text=men.
#Text=Women's participation in all aspects of a mission\r
#Text=can help to break down stereotypes held by women in\r
#Text=many local communities, especially where women\r
#Text=peacekeepers serve in a broad spectrum of the activities\r
#Text=of a mission.
#Text=This has had a spin-off effect on the\r
#Text=participation of local women in decision-making\r
#Text=positions.
#Text=Women political monitors are just as willing\r
#Text=and capable of serving in dangerous or isolated areas as\r
#Text=men, and do so just as effectively.
#Text=The study also shows that mixed teams of women\r
#Text=and men, a significant proportion of women team\r
#Text=leaders, women special representatives or heads of\r
#Text=mission, or a conscious effort by a special\r
#Text=representative to seek the best staff, whether women or\r
#Text=men, has a positive influence on the outcome.
#Text=Women\r
#Text=also respond by participating in the troop-contributing\r
#Text=countries' military and civilian police contingents.
#Text=The\r
#Text=Department of Peacekeeping Operations has made\r
#Text=strenuous efforts to encourage Member States to send\r
#Text=women on missions, on the basis of equity, as their\r
#Text=presence can assist in defusing potentially tense\r
#Text=situations.
#Text=Much more should be done in order to\r
#Text=encourage women to enter this service.
#Text=What do this and other studies tell us about what\r
#Text=local women do?
#Text=There is abundant evidence to show\r
#Text=that even when having to flee to safety with their\r
#Text=families or protecting them in refugee or displaced-\r
#Text=persons camps, women take on a number of peace-\r
#Text=building activities.
#Text=Women are active at both formal and informal\r
#Text=levels.
#Text=With few exceptions, women are not present in\r
#Text=formal peace negotiations.
#Text=However, women have been\r
#Text=part of these negotiations, as we saw in the field in\r
#Text=Burundi, and in Guatemala and South Africa.
#Text=Somali\r
#Text=women helped to bring the clan leaders back into the\r
#Text=negotiations at one stage and were permitted to join the\r
#Text=negotiations as observers.
#Text=Most of the activities, however, take place at the\r
#Text=informal level.
#Text=Grass-roots women's organizations in\r
#Text=several countries have sponsored peace education;\r
#Text=encouraged child soldiers to lay down arms; organized\r
#Text=groups advocating peace across party and ethnic lines;\r
#Text=organized campaigns against small arms, such as the\r
#Text=Organization of African Unity (OAU) African\r
#Text=Women's Committee on peace and development;\r
#Text=influenced repatriation processes and established\r
#Text=services for returning exiles, such as in Guatemala;\r
#Text=contributed to ending conflict; negotiated the release of\r
#Text=hostages; and established legal support groups to get\r
#Text=recognition for women's rights to land and household\r
#Text=property which may have been in the name of a spouse\r
#Text=killed or "disappeared" in a conflict.
#Text=Women at the local level are a rich resource\r
#Text=waiting to be systematically tapped by the international\r
#Text=community.
#Text=Many aspects of these informal activities\r
#Text=have been encouraged, supported financially and\r
#Text=documented by the United Nations and its agencies.
#Text=In\r
#Text=this connection, in addition to the work of the\r
#Text=Department of Peacekeeping Operations, the\r
#Text=Department of Political Affairs, the Office for the\r
#Text=Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the\r
#Text=Department for Disarmament Affairs should be\r
#Text=mentioned.
#Text=Special mention should also be made of the\r
#Text=work of the Office of the United Nations High\r
#Text=Commissioner for Refugees, the Office of the High\r
#Text=Commissioner for Human Rights, the United Nations\r
#Text=Children's Fund, the World Food Programme and the\r
#Text=World Health Organization.
#Text=The United Nations\r
#Text=Development Programme (UNDP), the United Nations\r
#Text=Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM) and the\r
#Text=United Nations Centre for Human Settlements\r
#Text=(Habitat) should also be credited with pioneering work\r
#Text=at the national and grass-roots levels.
#Text=Good practices\r
#Text=have been identified, studied and published, including\r
#Text=the study by the United Nations Research Institute for\r
#Text=Social Development, "Women and Post-Conflict\r
#Text=Reconstruction".
#Text=The exchange of information on these\r
#Text=practices has enabled the United Nations system to\r
#Text=encourage States engaged in rehabilitation to work in\r
#Text=partnership with and sustain women's groups and civil\r
#Text=society engaged in these essential but often\r
#Text=unrecognized activities.
#Text=Capacity-building for\r
#Text=leadership and governance led by UNDP and UNIFEM\r
#Text=has greatly facilitated women's ability to play\r
#Text=constructive roles.
#Text=These entities are all members of the\r
#Text=Administrative Committee on Coordination's Inter-\r
#Text=Agency Committee on Women and Gender Equality,\r
#Text=which I chair.
#Text=We have lately formed a Task Force on\r
#Text=Women and Peace and Security to strengthen\r
#Text=collaboration on this critical issue.
#Text=This brings me to our vision for the future.
#Text=The\r
#Text=basic blueprint appears in the Beijing Platform for\r
#Text=Action, the Beijing + 5 outcome document, the\r
#Text=Windhoek Declaration and the Namibia Plan of Action.
#Text=It also appears in the many powerful statements from\r
#Text=women's groups that we heard yesterday in the\r
#Text=Council's Arria-formula meeting.
#Text=The planning of any mission must include gender\r
#Text=equality aspects.
#Text=The mandate of the mission and the\r
#Text=guidelines for special representatives must clearly\r
#Text=indicate that gender considerations must be integrated\r
#Text=into the mission's goals and the head of mission be\r
#Text=accountable.
#Text=Each mission should have a plan for\r
#Text=incorporating gender issues into all aspects of the\r
#Text=mission's work.
#Text=There should be a gender unit,\r
#Text=adequately staffed and resourced to provide the\r
#Text=necessary backstopping on the mission site, and one in\r
#Text=DPKO for overall oversight.
#Text=I am pleased to state that\r
#Text=DPKO has established two such units- one in East\r
#Text=Timor and one in Kosovo - and gender focal points in\r
#Text=Sierra Leone and Western Sahara.
#Text=All sectors of the\r
#Text=transition or rebuilding process should take gender\r
#Text=issues into account.
#Text=Greater attention must be paid to\r
#Text=ensuring the appointment of women as special\r
#Text=representatives, in accordance with the Brahimi report\r
#Text=and the call by women heads of State and Government\r
#Text=of 5 September.
#Text=The Council may wish to ensure that\r
#Text=all the reports that it receives on missions contain\r
#Text=information and data on the extent to which a gender\r
#Text=perspective has been introduced and on the number and\r
#Text=level of women working in the various missions.
#Text=Working with the agencies on the ground, the political\r
#Text=and development wings of the mission should organize\r
#Text=the mobilization of community groups, especially\r
#Text=women's groups, and expand the pool of skills needed\r
#Text=to sustain the peace process.
#Text=A roster of such groups\r
#Text=could be kept by DPKO, in collaboration with regional\r
#Text=bodies and agencies.
#Text=The code of conduct for\r
#Text=peacekeepers should be regularly updated and where\r
#Text=there are infringements, there should be a continuation\r
#Text=of apprehension and discipline.
#Text=Should it be decided to\r
#Text=appoint a new assistant secretary-general in the\r
#Text=Department of Peacekeeping Operations, as proposed\r
#Text=in the Panel's report, strong consideration should be\r
#Text=given to appointing a woman to one of the three\r
#Text=assistant secretary-general posts in the Department.
#Text=In closing, may I recall the main finding of the\r
#Text=joint study made by the Department of Peacekeeping\r
#Text=Operations and the Division for the Advancement of\r
#Text=Women.
#Text=It was that the most important lesson learned\r
#Text=is that lessons are not always learned.
#Text=Lessons from\r
#Text=Namibia and South Africa had little effect on\r
#Text=Cambodia or Bosnia Herzegovina, for example.
#Text=Gender\r
#Text=equality issues are absolutely essential to the success of\r
#Text=any peace operation.
#Text=We cannot exclude half the\r
#Text=world's resources from participating in peace.
#Text=The fundamental human right to have and to\r
#Text=enjoy equality is a given.
#Text=It was emphasized by the\r
#Text=Beijing Conference and reaffirmed again in the\r
#Text=Beijing +5 outcome document and even more so at the\r
#Text=Millennium Declaration.
#Text=There can be no peace\r
#Text=without gender equality and no development without\r
#Text=both peace and equality.
#Text=Without the equal and fair\r
#Text=participation of women in decision-making positions in\r
#Text=the United Nations and also in Member States, as well\r
#Text=as in this central organ of the United Nations, we will\r
#Text=never achieve the vision outlined in the United Nations\r
#Text=Charter.
#Text=May this discussion and the decisions that\r
#Text=follow be those in which we demonstrate that, at least\r
#Text=in the area of women and peace and security, this is one\r
#Text=lesson that we have learned and intend to put into\r
#Text=action.
